whyItFailed: Load balancer distributes traffic but cannot create capacity. Without auto scaling, all servers get overwhelmed equally during traffic spikes.
More servers mean more database queries. Without caching, the database becomes the bottleneck regardless of how many compute instances are running.
Synchronous processing cannot absorb burst traffic. Without queues, requests pile up and timeout, causing cascading failures.
Malicious traffic consumed resources meant for legitimate users. Without WAF or rate limiting, the system scaled to serve attackers.
Running maximum capacity from the start burns budget before traffic arrives. Costs exceeded revenue, making the architecture unsustainable.
Stale data caused application errors and user complaints. Cache improved speed but broke data consistency.
Regional outage took down entire system. No geographic redundancy meant zero disaster recovery capability.
